You pull the walkie off your belt loop.

"Please help us!" Strauss cries. "The captain keeps shooting but it’s not doin—oh god."

Neil looks at you in horror. You click the button on side the side of the talkie. You say:

1.[["Hold on, Doc. We’re coming!"]]

"We'll hike down the wall and take our respective tunnels. You guys have that one on the right over there. See it?" she asks, pointing.

"Yeah," Meat says. "On it."

1. [["This is a plan I'm not crazy about."]]
2.	[["Roger, roger."]]

You decide to wait it out, see if you're not infected. Too bad you killed the only guy who had access to the autopilot controls. You can't even send a distress beacon now.

That's when you notice a wetness on your cheek. You touch it with your finger and pull back blood.

You're infected. However, you can't bring yourself to eat a bullet. You've been through too much. You decide to ride it out, see what happens.

Nothing good. Your fingernails fall off first. Then you start vomiting and shitting blood. Your teeth are next. At this point you decide that killing yourself is the best course of action, but you go blind before you can find your gun.

Days pass like this, with you lying on the floor, begging for death, unable to see anything. Finally, you feel a movement in your chest. A tremor.

And then you feel nothing at all.

The End.

"We can’t make him do this," Strauss interjects, finally saying something.

"Fuck it, run! Run!" Meat yells. He drops the rifle and runs into the kitchen. You aren’t far behind, jumping over a low slash from the tentacle. Right before you step inside, you see another writhing tentacle erupt from her body.

You slam the door and turn around. Strauss and Meat are looking over the bloody hole in Neil’s chest. Blood is dripping from the corner of Neil’s mouth. You hear another stretching sound follow by a splash outside. Another tentacle.

"Fuck me, fuck fuck fuck," Meat says, his voice dripping with guilt. "I’m so sorry."

Neil looks up at him. "Not your fault, big man. Wasn’t fast enough…"

"Stop talking, sweetie," Strauss says, taking you by surprise with the earnest care in her voice as she examines the wound. "An artery’s been pierced."

"Shit, is there anything you can do for him?"

Strauss looks at you both, clearly not wanting to give her answer in front of Neil. You feel a tap on your arm. Neil looks up at you.

"Zoe, come here."

You lean down.

"Cockpit. Computer login is…" he coughs up some blood. "login is ‘K-O-N-A-M-I. Got it?"

You slide into your chamber and the hatch closes. You quickly fall into slumber. When you wake up, you're surounded by soldiers. One of them, a corporal, is saying something but his words are soundless. He takes you by the arm and guides you up from the pod.

From there, you, the captain, and Meat are transported to the military outpost in New Austin. You are all given private rooms and access to nearly anything you could want. You order a steak on the first night and it's delicious.

Just as Meat said, men in suits come and interview you about your experiences on the Speedwell. You answer their questions in as much detail as you can. They thank you for your time and promise you will be released soon.

"Soon" turns out to be three days later. You, Meat, and Salvucci meet on the base and request a transport to the nearest bar. There, you all drink in almost complete silence, only uttering the names of the lost from time to time.

You all take seperate cabs home. When you reach your house in the suburbs, you pass your mailbox but decide to check it later. It's only when you swipe your card against the door's reader and hear it unlock that you feel as though you are truly safe. Inside, you shut the door and hang up your coat.

You go into the living room and sit on the couch. You do nothing but stare at the wall for hours, in a trance of sorts. You rub you finger up and down one of the cushions of your couch. You are alive to do this, but you're not sure you're thankful for that.

You begin to see a therapist. You make progress--according to him, anyway. You never really shake the memories of your time aboard the Speedwell, but you're able to cope with them.

That's more than can be said for Captain Salvucci, who eats a bullet on the third anniversary of your return to Mars. 

You don't go to the funeral.

You and Meat stay in contact but the emails you send one another are largely bullshit. Your failure to connect with him is indicative of your relationship with the rest of humankind. You never marry or even begin what you're comfortable calling a relationship with anyone. For the first ten years or so, this bothers you but you slowly grow comfortable with this new you.

You become a writer. Your sci-fi espionage novels sell well enough for you to live comfortably by yourself and away from everyone. You're mostly happy but sometimes there's a thought strikes you like the lash of a whip.

You are alone.

The End

You take careful aim and fire a single shot that pierces Ryan's visor and kills him instantly. The squad vital monitor shrieks as he flatlines.

The monster roars again and then you catch a glimpse of its hideous, reptilian face as it darts out and closes its jaws around Ryan’s head. Like fingers plucking a grape from a vine, the beast rips out your squadmate’s head, leaving a bloody stump of a neck.

You flee.

You run and run and run. You lose feeling in your legs but somehow manage to keep going full speed anyway. Near the end, you swear that your heart is going to burst and that your lungs will catch on fire, but eventually you stumble out of the tunnel into the irradiated light of dusk.

Across the way, you can see Meat assisting a limping Markie. Behind them, you glimpse small purple mushroom shapes scuttling across the sand. You run toward your squadmates. You’ve covered half the distance when, looking up, you see the Speedwell beginning its descent.

When you reach them, Meat hands Markie off to you and turns to fire several rounds at the crab creatures. He tags all of them except for one. 

You watch helplessly as the little bastard leaps through the air and, with tentacles shooting out from its underbelly, wraps itself around Markie’s arm.

She screams in pain. You whip out your empty pistol and bash the monster’s dome in. The creature lets go of her arm and falls to the ground, legs squiggling. Its agony is short-lived, as Meat puts three rounds into the soft belly.

"Fucking fuck." He kicks the crab.

You turn to Markie, who’s holding her arm. 

1.[["Is your suit ripped?"]]

"Fuck it. Let’s get her aboard. We'll worry about what happened later."

You and Meat help Markie to the ship’s elevator. Meat enters a combination on the keypad and the door slides open.  Inside the elevator, as you ride up, all three of you remove your helmets. You notice for the first time that your face is drenched in sweat.

A ding. The door opens. Captain Jonas Salvucci, an older, muscular man with little patience for tomfoolery, awaits you—his hand wrapped around the pistol in his holster.

He takes his hand away from the gun when he sees there’s no threat.

"Get her to sickbay."

You nod and help Markie through the hallway of the ship. Behind you, you can hear Salvucci interrogating Meat.

"What happened to Ryan?"

"He's dead, cap. Something got him."

"Hell, Travis. What did you find down there?"

When you get to sickbay, both Lenore Strauss, the doctor, and her geeky assistant Ben are prepping the examination table.

"Where’s she wounded?" Lenore asks, as you help a woozy Markie out of her suit.  You glare at Ben as he gawks at her well-toned body. He smiles sheepishly and looks away, cheeks burning red with shame. Markie’s drenched in sweat; she stares around wildly while Lenore straps her in. She examines the bite: it’s just above the elbow, an inflamed bulging of the skin.

"And I was young and we were running," Markie rambles, "eyes bouncing up and down the shore  while the sun cooked the corpses of washed up jellyfish."

You turn to Lenore; she's prepping some kind of tool.

1.[["What’s she saying?"]]
2.[["What is that?"]]

"One of us needs to lead it there," Strauss says. "Play wounded. Beg for help. The others have to hang back otherwise it won't fall for the trick."

"Me neither, but she ain't wrong," Meat says grimly. "Somebody's got to be ready to put it all on the line for this."

"I'll go," Strauss says.

Meat doesn't contain his shock. "What?"

"I think we've already established I'm helpless, which means that thing has too. It'll come running."

"This is fucking crazy. Cap, we can't send her out there. I'll go," Meat says.

"You're the biggest of us. It won't go after you, not until it's killed everyone else off. It has to be me."

Salvucci furrows his brow. He unholsters his pistol and hands it to Strauss. "I want my gun back, doctor. Be careful."

"Yes sir."

She nods.

Meat glares at Strauss but she continues.

You watch as he presses some buttons on the console and turns to you.

"So, how do you want to do thi--" he's only begun to show fear when you shoot him in the face. He flops to the floor. You carefully step past him and look out into the darkness of space.

You realize the few loved ones you have at home will never know what happened to you. You will die a mystery. You put the gun to your temple and pull the trigger.

You cast your light on the protruding spike and realize, as your comrade is slowly being lifted in the air, that it’s a limb of some sort.

Markie’s voice barks over the comm. "Julia! What’s happening? Ryan’s vitals are dropping." You fire several shots into the darkness. One of them slaps into Ryan’s arm; his blue eyes gaze at you in shock.

Meat now: "Julia? Answer us, girl. What the fuck is going on?"

"Meat, you go check on Neil. Zoe and I are going to look for Strauss."

"What should we do about them? They might, y’know, come back."

"Knock that horror movie shit off, Travis."

"Captain, with all due respect, I think we’re pretty well entrenched in horror movie territory right about now, oh with the crazy alien women and two dead crew members. Is it too much to humor me when I ask for a little reassurance?"

Salvucci frowns. "What are you suggesting?"

Meat looks down at the corpses. "I need oil. We can use the lab’s emergency coolant system to control the blaze."

Salvucci nods solemnly. "Run to engineering. Grab what you need. Burn the bodies."

1.[["Are you two serious? This is insane!"]]
2.[["Burn 'em."]]

"What about the bodies? Do you think Strauss will come back?"

1.[["Burn her just to be sure."]]
2.[["She won’t."]]

Strauss closes her eyes and momentarily bites her lip. "I’m a coward."

Salvucci holsters his gun. "There’s nothing you could have done, doctor. Let’s go."

Strauss looks up, her remorse stowed away or perhaps an illusion. "What about the creature?"

"Meat’s burning the bodies."

Her eyes widen. "Why the everliving hell is that lumbering mountain of idiocy doing such a thing?"

"He thinks they might come back."

"That fucking moron! We don’t know how that infection works. It could be twice as deadly as an airborne virus. I need those bodies intact. Call him! Stop him!"

Salvucci's face goes pale. "I don’t have a walkie."

"Run," she says.

And you do. As fast as you can. Inside sickbay you find Meat, sitting down on the floor, staring at where the bodies should be, but instead there’s only a lot of blood and some meaty chunks.

An oil can, a bottle, and a rag are next to Meat.

"Where are they?"  Strauss demands. "The bodies? Where are they?"

"Oh good. You’re alive," Meat says. You can feel the force of his eyeroll from here.

"Where are the bodies? Did you burn them?"

"No, doctor. As you would have gathered from the lack of smoke if you weren’t a nutcase, I have not burned a damn thing. I came back and they were gone."

Strauss approaches Meat, gets in his face. "Well did they just fucking get up and walk off?"

He yells back. "I don’t know! You’re supposed to be the doctor here."

"Everyone relax," Salvucci says, voice raised.  Meat and Strauss calm down, each refusing to look at the other, each saying nothing.

"We’ve got two missing bodies, possibly infected and mutated into hostile lifeforms." Salvucci rubs his forehead. "I need thoughts, suggestions, anything. Where should we go from here?" He turns to you first. 

1.[["Let's go see Neil."]]
2.[["I'm ready to go hunting."]]

"Best goddamn thing I've heard on this stupid voyage. Let's go."

You both head to the cryogenics room and ready your pods. They hiss and spew cold air on you as they open.

"Two months," he says as he stares at the tube, which you realize now looks very much like a coffin. "Here’s hoping nothing eats us while we’re sleeping."

He gets in his. You follow suit.

"See you soon, lady."

You press the button on the interior door and it slowly closes on your tube. You hear the seal clamp. A mist falls over your face.

You slowly closes your eyes and desperately hope you wake up.

It’s as though no time passes between the moment the darkness falls over you to when you open your eyes again to see ten soldiers standing over you, peering down, each of them equipped with assault rifles.

"Come on, lieutenant," one of them says, lifting you to your feet. You see Meat being held up by two soldiers. He’s grinning like a fool.

"We did it," his eyes say.

The troops escort you both to your own personal rooms where you’re served cheap stake and soda pop. It tastes superb. Later, you and Meat are interviewed about the incident aboard the Speedwell. You both answer the interviewer, an older man with a bald spot, as honestly as you can.

And then he shows you security footage of you and Meat killing Strauss.

"Explain," he says. Before you can even say anything, Meat jumps in. "The bitch murdered the captain. She would have killed us too. You bet I fucking killed her."

And just like that, his confession damns you. You're both court-martialed. You both get life.

You live within the walls of Titan penitentiary for 22 more years. On the first day in prison, another woman tries to force herself on you in the showers, a shank in her hand. The guards find her later with the makeshift blade buried in her eye; her tongue has been removed and placed next to her.

Eventually, the other inmates come to respect you enough that you become the most powerful person in the prison. You can get almost anything you want: TVs, movies, games, gourmet food. Sometimes someone says something disrespectful; you are ruthless in dispatching them. Everyone and everything is your property.

In the twenty-second year of your reign, another upstart conspires to have you murdered. She posions a pie later brought to your cell. You die alone, reaching toward the ceiling as your insides are burned away.

The End

Neil nods at you one last time. You make your way to the vent where Meat has just finished prying off the cover. The gas is thick in the air, making you slightly dizzy.

"Tight fit," he says. "I’ll go first so I can remove the next cover."

Strauss follows Meat. You look back to see that multiple tentacles have penetrated the door. Neil is pointing the pistol in the air and is breathing hard.

You force down the feeling of despair in your stomach and crawl through the vent. When you catch up to Strauss and Meat, he’s already kicking a cover.

"Almost got it!" With one last kick, the cover comes free. Meat grabs Strauss and pulls her through.You emerge into the hallway just in time to feel the ship shake violently.

Meat slams his fist into the wall over and over. Strauss looks on sadly.

1.[["Hey! Focus. I need you here. We can stew in our guilt later, got that?"]]
2. [[Leave him be.]]

You and Jack choose not to have kids. You never regret the choice, and Jack doesn't seem to either, though you do wonder what your life would be like if you had children.

You make enough money to retire. You grow old and stop shaving your legs because who gives a fuck? Jack's hair goes white first. Yours follows shortly. You decide not to get anti-aging treatments. 

You wake up one morning to find your husband cold on the patio. You get down on the floor and hold his corpse for hours before you finally dial the operator and tell the poor man on the other end that your husband is dead and you have no clue what to do. He takes your address and promises he'll send an ambulance.

They come. Your heart shatters when they zip him in a bag.

Later, weeks after the funeral, Meat comes to stay for a couple of weeks. He’s bald and uses a cane because of a bum leg. You watch reruns of Farscape: The Next Story and play chess. You talk of your loved ones.  Then, he brings it up: "Do you ever think of them? The crew?"

1. [["I do."]]
2. [["I don't."]]
3. [["What's the point?"]]

column1: "I've got at least two rounds left."
column2: "I'm not ready to call it quits yet. There's got to be a way to kill that thing without guns. We just gotta improvise."\n\n1.[["The hanger. We can use the hanger."]]

"Good. Give me your gun and turn the gas on before you leave."

"There’s no way out except through the front."

"Vent," he says, pointing at a vent near one of the stoves. "…Gotta crawl fast. I’ll give you as much time as I can."

A clanging at the door. Whatever was inside Markie is now trying to get in the kitchen.

"This ain’t fucking right, man. It’s not right at all."

"Just give me your damn gun, dude." He coughs. Meat, with reluctance, takes the pistol from his holster and sticks it in Neil’s hand. He then goes from stove to stove, turning on the gas.

Another bang at the door. The tip of a tentacle pierces the door and writhes wildly about, slapping a nearby wall.

"Go," Neil says, fighting to stay conscious.

1.[["I'm so sorry, Neil."]]
2. [[Don't say anything to him.]]

"I dream of them from time to time," he says. "I miss them." 

That’s all he says on the matter. The week passes. He leaves. His wife, Rhonda, calls you a month later to tell you he passed away in his sleep. You can’t make the funeral because traveling would make your ailing health even worse.

You wait. You spend days watching old movies. You try to make your way through a collection of Christine Love’s works, but you keep losing your focus.

Death comes when you’re sitting in your loveseat watching a news report on a bridge being built in a neighboring county. It is a quick, painful tremor that starts in your chest and spreads out.

The dark sets in. You never expected slipping away to be this easy.

The End

"God," Salvucci says, holstering his weapon.

"And then there were three," Neil says.

"We're probably infected too," Salvucci says quietfully.

"But there's been no symptoms yet."

"What if they never show up until years later? When we're back on Mars."

"Then a doctor could take care of us or something, man."

You see Salvucci slowly reach for his pistol again. "I can't take that risk. If our survival puts humanity in danger...."

"Cap," Neil says, backing into the wall. "Think straight here."

"I'm sorry, Neil. I'm sure Julia agrees."

1. [[Die.]]
2. [[Don't die yet.]]

The mess hall is rather small: two tables next to an enclosed kitchen. You find Meat sitting at by himself, shoveling ramen into his mouth. A plastic cup filled with cheap whiskey is next to his arm. You grab your favorite snack, baked potato chips, and take a seat.

Meat looks up at you, eyes red, a weary expression.

"Hell of a day, huh? Poor Ryan. How's Markie? How are you?"

1.[["Strauss is taking her freakin' arm off."]]
2.[["Cut the shit. You know how my day's been."]]

Without a word to your companions, you dash across the room and grab the hose. The freezing gas pours over your pants and chest. The cold nearly makes you drop the hose--it's like you've fallen into freezing water.

Markie makes a beeline for you. You lock eyes with Salvucci. Luckily, he understands and raises his pistol.

You brace yourself as Markie slams into you. Both of you fall to the ground, the hose pointed upward into the chest of the creature. The monster unleashes a hellish scream as you push up as hard as you can. The hose hisses. 

You hear Meat yell something. And then a loud pop. A weight is lifted off your chest as Markie falls to the right, but you know not to let up: you aim the hose to the right. Through the mist, you see her flailing about.

Something grabs you and forces you to let go of the hose. It drags you away to the corner of the room. You feel cold inside. Every breath hurts...and your hand feels lighter. 

Through blurred vision, you watch as Salvucci approaches Markie, each footsteep dispelling the mist, and points his sidearm down at her face. He fires, shattering her hideous, frozen visage.

You did it: she's dead.

"Captain!" Meat yells, he's looking down at you, eyes filled with panic. "Get over here."

Sleep takes you.

1. [[Awaken.]]

He sighs. "I want to believe you, but...nevermind. What now?"

1.[["We sleep."]]

column1: Look into her eyes as she dies.
column2:
You stare into her eyes as the life is choked out of her by your companion. She reaches for you helplessly but then her arm goes limp.

"Dude, stop!" Neil yells, but Meat doesn't. A minute later, Strauss has stopped moving altogether. The light's gone out of her eyes. Meat lets her corpse drop to the floor. 

Neil moans in horror. "Travis..."

"She would have killed us, man; the moment she saw any of us as a threat, she would have killed as without a thought, just to save her sorry hide. Good riddance."

Meat lights up his molotov and throws it atop Ben and the captain's corpses.

"So, uh, what do we do now?" Neil asks after a long bout of silence.

"We're not done hunting, Neil."

"With what? You saw what bullets did to Ben: took a whole damn clip and then some."

"We'll have to improvise, won't we? I don't know about you, but I sure as fuck don't plan on being some monster's dinner."

1.[["We need to draw it out into the open."]]

column1: "Cut the shit. You know how my day's been."
column2:
He sighs. "Figured as much."

The PA clicks on: "All officers report to sickbay," Salvucci says.

Meat gobbles up the rest of his food and grabs the rifle leaning upright against the table. You realize that you’re out of ammo, so you take one of the clips from your belt and reload the pistol.

The door is open when you get there. Salvucci, Lenore, and Ben are standing around a bloody examination bed. You look to the right: Markie, one arm missing, is sequestered in a see-through quarantine cube. She’s looking around wildly.

You smell gunsmoke. Ben has both of his hands wrapped around his pistol.

1.[["Why weren't we invited to the party?"]]
2.[["Something happened, huh?"]]

"Fuck that!" Meat says, turning. He aims his assault rifle at the first speaker and dismembers it with a single shot. He takes the second and third speakers out of commission as well. The music is no longer overpowering, but you can hear its echoes in the hallway.

"Brutal, but effective," Strauss comments.

Salvucci frowns. "You’re footing the bill for that when we get back."

"Guys, now that Zoe is awake, I think we should talk strategy. I just finished with our travel projections…" Neil says.

"And?" Strauss says, as though she knows what’s coming next.

"Well, it’s like you said, doc: not good. Two months to Mars."

"We could last that long," Salvucci says. "We ration food, ammo, go in groups to the rest of the ship when we need supplies."

"Captain, permission to speak?" Meat says.

Salvucci nods.

"That’s a horrible idea. We’ve got guns. Why don’t we use them? For all we know, that beastie thing could be growing. We need to hunt it down and kill it now."

"Travis, I put a gun against Markie’s head and blew her brains all over the floor. Apparently the thing inside her shook it off and walked away. I don’t think bullets are going to save us."

"Then we destroy the body completely," Meat suggests. "Shoot it, stomp it, burn it, and then jettison the motherfucker into space."

"Captain, I don’t like either choice, but I think the more cautious one would be eliminating its presence from the ship," Strauss says slowly.

"Didn’t you say something about it being airborne?" Salvucci asks. "Could killing it infect one of us?"

Strauss sighs, shrugs. "There’s no way to be sure. I didn’t get to run any tests on it. However, I’d rather take a chance on that possibility than risk us starving ourselves into easy prey."

Silence fills the common room. Then—

"What do you think, Zoe?" Neil asks.

Everyone turns to you.

1.[["Let's go kill it."]]
2.[["We should wait it out."]]

"Easy for you to say, Zoe. You’re not the one who’s being served up as dinner."

Meat slaps Neil on the shoulder. "We won’t let you get eaten, okay?"

"You’re not making this any more appealing."

He takes a breath. "Okay, well, how are we going to do this?"
"We’ll go to the cafeteria--big, open space."

You all make your way to the cafeteria, eyes watching the walls and vents. The journey is a safe one. 

All of you step into the cafeteria.

Neil looks out across the tables like a man looking at his own grave.

"I always thought lunchrooms were kind of scary when I was a kids, ‘cause of the bullies and all. Never thought I’d die in one, though."

"You’ll be fine," Meat says. "We’ll be in the other room. You’re gonna stay in here and use your walkie."

"To do what?"

"Be bait. Make helpless noises."

"How’s it gonna hear that?"

"Marki—what used to be Markie has a walkie clipped to her belt."

"And if she thinks it’s a trap?"

"She won't, okay?" Meat says as you and he make your way to the kitchen door.

"I can’t believe this shit."

You and Meat step into the kitchen and move away from the door. He turns to you. "Make sure you have your gun ready, okay? I don’t want Neil to get eaten because we ran dry."

You check your pistol to make sure it has a full clip and nod.

You both silently and listen to Neil in the other room. "Please help me," you hear him beg. "I can’t find you guys."
This goes on for 20 whole minutes, Neil’s acting growing steadily worse. "I fucking hurt my leg," he whimpers.

"He's clearly never taken a drama class," Meat says.

"Oh fuck," Neil says urgently. 

1. [[Give Meat the walkie.]]

"Damn. Do you hear that?"

Footsteps. Giant footsteps.

"Let's go."

You both retreat to the hanger.

"Shit," he says as the door slides shut behind you. "I thought this thing was bigger."

He’s right: it’s not much, and half the room is cramped by the reconnaissance droids.

"Loosen the holding clamps on those. I’ll get our suits. Hurry, it can’t be far behind us."

You deactivate the locks on the droids and catch the suit that Meat throws you. You’re just about to put the helmet on when you hear the clanging on the door.

"Shit. It’s here. When it gets in front of the droids, shoot the hanger switch, okay? And for fuck’s sake, hold on to something."

1.	[["Stay safe."]]

The sight of the bandaged nub makes you sick.

"Told you not to look at it."

He wheels you down to the cryo room where Neil and Salvucci are waiting.

"There's captain kickass herself!" the pilot says. "Oh don't look so put out, I'll buy you a foam finger when we get back to Mars."

1.[["Fuck. You."]]
2. [[Laugh.]]

He gives a weak laugh. "Can't argue with that." He looks out across the hall to the viewport where stars, endless and bright, can be seen.

"I really wish things hadn't turned out this way," he says.

Those are the last words he says to you. He goes to sleep later and doesn't wake up. You stare at his pale body sprawled out on the floor. Your belly rumbles weakly.

1. [[Resort to cannibalism.]]
2. [[Starve.]]

Before you can answer, Strauss slams the fist of her unwounded arm against the door.

"Listen here, you little shit. You open this door right now or so help me I’ll put you to sleep, slather whatever honey we have left in the cafeteria on your testicles, and we’ll use you as bait for the fucking monster."

The door slides open. Neil’s face, boyish as ever, awaits you and Strauss. He is unharmed.

"It eats honey?"

"I don’t think I’ll ever be able to fathom the depths of your stupidity, pilot."

Neil frowns; he seems genuinely hurt by the remark.

1.[["Come on. Let's just go."]]
2.[["Stop dicking around, Neil."]]
3.[["Don't be such a bitch, Strauss."]]

You snatch the gun from his holster and shoot him in the shin. He falls to the ground screaming in pain.

"The fuck, Zoe?!"

You back away from him, pistol aimed at his head.

1.[["Come after me and I'll vent your head."]]
2. [[Say nothing and leave.]]

Before the words can leave your mouth, there’s a whooshing sound, followed by a giant spike tearing through Ryan’s chest, splattering the cave with red. Ryan’s pistol drops to the floor. He moans. 

You cast your light on the protruding spike and realize, as your comrade is slowly being lifted in the air, that it’s a tail or a limb of some sort.

Markie’s voice barks over the comm. "Zoe! What’s happening!? Ryan’s vitals are dropping." You fire several shots into the darkness. One of them slaps into Ryan’s arm; his blue eyes gaze at you in shock.

Meat now: "Zoe? Answer us, girl. What the fuck is going on?"

1.[["We need to go. Now!"]]
2.[["Ryan's chum."]]

Meat now: "Julia? Answer us, girl. What the fuck is going on?"

1.[["Get the Speedwell here now!"]]

He looks away sheepishly. "Sorry."

"Stop trying to hit that, Ryan. It’s not gonna happen," says Markie, the Speedwell's science officer.

Ryan waves his hands dismissively. 

The enforcer of the group, Meat, chuckles. "She told you."

1. [[Wink at Markie in appreciation.]]

"Not a damn trace" Meat says before swallowing a chip. "Not in Engineering, the cafeteria, the cryo room. We checked every nook and cranny. My guess is that they’re in the vents."

"This is some fucked up shit," Neil says.

"Eloquent as always, pilot."

"We should move shop," Meat says after a moment. "This facility has two doors. I don’t like that. Captain and I were talking; the common room is more safe and it’s closer to the cafeteria. We can make supply runs."

"…while we—what? Wait for the creature to die?" Strauss asks.

"That’s the plan. We stay safe, let it starve."

"And what if it can wait longer than us? What if that’s part of the thing’s plan? Wait till we get sick and hungry enough for it to overpower us. Did you even bother thinking about the logistics of that move, you dunce? Cryosleep is part of the ship’s travel. We don’t have enough food on board to support us until we reach earth. We have maybe a month at the most before we run out. Then what?"

"I don’t know, okay? I hear a lot of criticism but I don’t hear you contributing anything else, doctor."

Strauss scowled. "That’s because I’m trying to prevent you from leading us into a disaster."

"Can it, the both of you," Salvucci commands. "Meat’s right as far as safety precautions go. The common room will be easier to forify and protect than this place. We can worry about long-term plans once we get set up there. Doc, you and Neil grab whatever supplies you think we might need from in here. Travis, you and Zoe make a trip to the cafeteria, bag some grub, meet us in the common room. Be. Careful."

"Yeah, boss. Got it," Meat says. "Come on, Zoe."

The two of you leave as Strauss, Neil, and Salvucci retrieve medical supplies.	

"You and the captain should have put a round in her when you found her," Meat says as you walk toward the cafeteria.

1.[["We can't turn on each other, man."]]
2.[["You and her are gonna get us all killed if you keep bickering."]]
3.[["Tempting. It was very, very tempting."]]

column1: "Come after me and I'll vent your head."
column2:
You hear him call your name as you turn and sprint down the hall.

Fool, it says. I offered you evolution, wretch.

Blood drips from your nose. There's a pain in your stomach. You have to hurry.

You reach the hanger within a minute and seal the door behind you. There's a wetness on your lips now.

You approach the hanger door and place your hand over the release button. Your legs go numb and you fall to the floor, hand still held against the button. You press it and close your eyes. There's a whoosing sound as air is sucked past you, stinging your cheeks.

The first thing you feel is the cold. You open your eyes to see the Speedwell in all its glory as you drift away. The thing in your brain screams in anger and despair, but another voice cuts through. "Just let go," Markie says, her voice free of malice and madness.

You turn away from your ship and peer out across the ocean of stars to gaze at what you think is the sun in the far distance. It's quite pleasant from afar.

You take her advice.

The End

You and Meat follow the captain to cockpit. Neil, the ship’s pilot, sits at the controls. He smiles when the three of you enter; he has a thing for you, but he’s an idiot.

"Hello darling."

"Cut the shit, Neil."

"Yes, captain," he says, deflated.

"Meat take over the co-pilot controls for Markie." 

Meat nods, takes a seat. Neil looks over at him. "You’re a bit pale, big boy. Something happen?"

"Shut the fuck up, Neil. Just do your job."

"Sheesh."

Salvucci turns to you. "Okay, I need you to be straight with me: what are we dealing with? Do you think she’s going to turn into whatever killed Ryan?"

"Woah, shit," Neil says, turning in his seat. "Ryan’s dead? What happened?"

"Leave it alone," Meat says.

"Zoe?" Salvucci says.

1.[["Whatever it is, we've got enough firepower to put it down."]]
2.[["Do I look like a fucking scientist, cap?"]]

Salvucci is talking when you head over. You can see that Strauss is smiling, but it’s a sad smile.

"She was a strong individual," Salvucci says. "I’ve had her on four voyages. One time, three years back, we were all on Jupiter at the hanger and everyone was boarding, and this guy sets off the detector. He opens his shirt and reveals enough explosives to decimate every person in the hanger. Meat, Me, couple of others have got out guns trained on him, but Markie–-she talked him down. She saw what nobody else saw: he was just a stupid kid gripped in the thrall of some fundamentalist nonsense. She saved at least one life that day, probably more."

"She was a good solider," Strauss says sadly.

1.[["You bet your ass she was."]]
2.[["It's pretty funny, you saying that, when you were ready to pull her down a couple of hours ago. Just sayin'"]]

The words aren't out of your mouth when you hear it again: scuttling, and then something else--a high pitched whine that sends a shiver down your spine.

"We're not alone," Meat says, voice low.

"What's that?" you hear Ryan say over your comm.

"There's something in here with us. We're turning back."

Meat nods at you and you both slowly back away. You pull out your pistol.

"What do you see, Meat?" Markie asks.

"Dunno. Don't like it whatever it is."

The whine again. You focus your eyes and see something moving in the dark.

Meat sees it, too. He fires at it. As muzzle flash fills the cave with brief spells of light you see that the creature isn't one thing, but many things with feelers and sharp teeth.

They rush toward you, hundreds of them.

"Let's get out of here!" Meat yells.

1. [[Shoot them.]]
2. [[Run away.]]

"Thanks," he utters, looking away from you.

"What about Markie?" Meat asks.

We have to euthanize her," Strauss says, looking through the glass at Markie. "The infection could spread."

"I thought you chopped her damn arm off so that wouldn’t happen."

"The possibility of infection still remains and, as I’m sure Julia can attest to, officer Daniels has only worsened in the past half hour. I’d say there’s at least a fifty percent chance  that what happened to the arm will happen to her."

"The arm was bad enough, captain," Ben says. "It took three rounds to kill it."

"We have no idea what kind of beast she’ll devolve into—"

"If she turns in the first place. God damn it. This is a fucking human being we’re talking about," Meat yells.

"Keep your cool, Travis," Salvucci commands. 

"Captain, if she turns into something, I’m not sure we’ll be able to contain it. Protocol states—’

"To hell with your protocol! That’s Markie we’re talking about. And you said it’s a fifty percent chance. That ain’t a sure thing. Not by a long shot."

"Do you really want to bet everyone’s lives on a single coin toss?"

"Let’s just keep her in the cube until something happens, then we decide what to do with her. I’ve got my rifle. Everybody else has pistols."

"Yes, because an assault rifle worked wonders for Sergeant Benson, didn’t it?"

Meat glares at Strauss but she continues.

"Mark my words, if we don’t take care of that thing, it’s going to take care of us."

The conversation is becoming heated. The captain seems uncertain what to do. You grip the pistol in your hand more tightly.

1.[["Everybody chill the fuck out."]]
2.[["Captain, say something."]]
3. [[Shoot Markie.]]

"Mess hall it is."

The four of you proceed carefully through the hallways of the ship.

"Hey, should we be worried about the pilot?" Strauss asks as you near the mess hall.

"He has a steel door protecting him. As long as he doesn't leave the cockpit he'll be fine."

"Yeah, but doe he know not to leave?" Strauss asks.

"He never leaves the cockpit."

"Do you really want to risk his life on that confidence?"

"Since when did you start to care so much about people who wer--"

"Don't finish that sentence, Travis."

1. [[Send someone to check on Neil.]]
2. [[Continue toward the mess hall.]]

"Dead. He's dead," she says again.

Above you you hear the road of the Speedwell's thruster as the ship lands. The sound frightens the fungal crabs back into their home.

You and Meat help Markie to the ship’s elevator. Meat enters a combination on the keypad and the door slides open.  

Inside the elevator, as you ride up, all three of you remove your helmets. You notice for the first time that your face is drenched in sweat.

A ding. The door opens. Captain Jonas Salvucci, an older, muscular man with little patience of tomfoolery, awaits you—-his hand wrapped around the pistol in his holster.
He takes his hand away from the gun when he sees there’s no threat.

"Get her to sickbay."

You nod and help Markie through the hallway of the ship. She's delerious now, stumbling. Behind you, you can hear Salvucci interrogating Meat.

"What happened to Ryan?"

"I dunno. I think the blood on Markie's suit isn't all hers, though."

"Damn it, Travis. What did you find down there?"

When you get to sickbay, both Lenore Strauss, the doctor, and her geeky assistant Ben are prepping the examination table.

"Where’s she wounded?" Lenore asks, as you help a woozy Markie out of her suit.  

You glare at Ben as he gawks at her well-toned body. He smiles sheepishly and looks away, cheeks burning red with shame. Markie’s drenched in sweat; she stares around wildly as Lenore straps her in. She examines the bite; it’s just above the elbow, an inflamed bulging of the skin.

"And I was young and we were running," Markie rambles, "eyes bouncing up and down the shore  while the sun cooked the corpses of washed up jellyfish."

You turn to Lenore, who’s prepping some kind of tool.

1. [["What the hell is she saying?"]]

He looks away sheepishly. "Sorry."

"Stop trying to hit that, Ryan. It’s not gonna happen," says Markie, the Speedwell's science officer.

Ryan waves his hand dismissively.

The enforcer of the group, Meat, chuckles. "She told you."

column2:

Meat is the one who picks you up from the hospital and drives you home.

You make enough money to retire. You grow old and stop shaving your legs, because who gives a fuck? Melissa’s hair goes white first. Yours follows shortly. You decide not to get anti-aging treatments. 

You wake up one morning to find your wife cold on the kitchen floor. You get down on the floor and hold her corpse for hours before you finally call the operator and tell the poor man on the other end that your wife is dead and you have no clue what to do. He takes your address and promises he'll send an ambulance.

column1: "Screaming isn't going to get us anywhere."
column2:
"You're right. Let's, uh, let's go to the cockpit. Set a course for Mars."

You follow Neil to the cockpit. Halfway there he stumbles and nearly falls. "I'm okay!" he says. "I'm okay."

In the cockpit, Neil nearly trips when he gets to the console, curses; he turns to you and his face goes pale.

"You're bleeding...from your eyes."

You feel the wetness on your cheek. You put a finger to the wetness and come away with a red smattering. You look at Neil and see that he's bleeding from his nose. After a second, he notices too.

"I guess we're both infected now. Shit."

1.[["You know what we have to do."]]

You and the bride-to-be get along well. She proves to be invaluable emotional support after Melissa dies from a stroke.

Shortly after the funeral, Meat comes to visit and stays a couple of weeks.

He’s bald and uses a cane because of a bum leg. You watch reruns of Friends 2041 and play chess. You talk of your loved ones and your children and then, unexpectedly, he brings it up.

"Do you ever think of them? The crew?"

column1: "I guess that means you’re useless in a fight."
column2:
"Yes," she says. "I guess it does, doesn't it?"

The two of you proceed down the main hallway. The silence is heavy, and Strauss seems to be deep in her own thoughts.

1.	[["What's waiting for you on Mars?"]]
2.	[["What’s up with you and Meat anyway?"]]

Strauss is waiting for you when you step outside. She’s holding her arm. There’s a patch of red coming through the white sleeve right above her elbow.

"It’s not a bite," she says, noticing your stare. "I fell when I was running and my arm took the fall."

1.[["Oh good, that means your ass is useless in a fight."]]
2.[["Don't strain yourself; I don't want to be scooping you off the ground while I'm trying to shoot something."]]

Just as Meat said, men in suits come and interview you about your experiences on the Speedwell. You answer their questions in as much detail as you can. They thank you for your time and promise you will be released soon.

"Soon" turns out to be three days later. You, Meat, and Salvucci meet on the base and request a transport to the nearest bar. There, you all drink in almost complete silence, only uttering the names of the lost from time to time.

You all take seperate cabs home. When you reach your house in the suburbs, you pass your mailbox but decide to check it later. It's only when you swipe your card against the door's reader and hear it unlock that you feel as though you are truly safe. Inside, you shut the door and hang up your coat.

You go into the living room and sit on the couch. You do nothing but stare at the wall for hours, in a trance of sorts. You rub you finger up and down one of the cushions of your couch. You are alive to do this, but you're not sure you're thankful for that.

You begin to see a therapist. You make progress--according to him, anyway. You never really shake the memories of your time aboard the Speedwell, but you're able to cope with them.

That's more than can be said for Captain Salvucci, who eats a bullet on the third anniversary of your return to Mars. You don't go to the funeral.

You and Meat stay in contact but the emails you send one another are largely going through the motions bullshit. You never send a word to one another that is true. Your failure to connect with him is indicative of your relationship with the rest of humankind. You never marry or even begin what you're comfortable calling a relationship with anyone. For the first ten years or so, this bothers you but you slowly grow comfortable with this new you.

You become a writer. Your sci-fi erotica, written under a pseudonym, sells well enough for you to live comfortably by yourself and away from everyone. You're mostly happy but sometimes there's a thought that strikes at like a whip.

You are alone.
